name: Yellow-faced Myna
description: It got its name from the large, bare, yellow skin patches around the eyes. Otherwise, it is black, with white under-tail coverts and a yellow undertail.
spread_note: Western Papua, New Guinea, and surrounding small islands
image_alt: Yellow-faced Myna, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
reproduction: Females lay 1â€“2 eggs; incubation lasts 14 days (data from captivity)
attractions: It is likely monogamous, forming lifelong pairs. It is often seen foraging with other fruit-eating birds. It frequently waits on perches for insects and other invertebrates, similar to some raptors.
breeding: We have kept them since 2008, achieving the first successful breeding in 2010.
